 ETHIOPIA NATIONAL FERTILIZER SECTOR PROJECT I. BACKGROUND A. The Macro Setting 1.1 Ethiopia, with a population of 54.8 million, is Sub-Saharan Africa's second most populous country. Its social indicators are among the lowest in the world very low 1994 per capita GDP at US$125 per year. high infant mortality rate of 122 per 1,000 live births, mortality rate of over 20 percent for children under five, and growing chronic protein energy malnutrition. According to TGE's Rural Nutrition Survey (1992), 64 percent of the children are stunted and 47 percent are underweight. Only 17 percent of children complete four years of primary school against the regional and global averages of 48 and 68 percent, respectively. 1.2 Over 50 percent of Ethiopians suffer from chronic food insecurity. The estimated average per capita calorie intake is below 80 percent of the level considered necessary for a healthy life. The country's structural food deficit, estimated to be around one million tons, is growing (Graph 1.1). In the last two decades, population growth averaged about 3 percent per annum, and is projected in the 1993 World Development Report, 1993 to grow at 2.7 percent per year until the turn of the century. 1.3 The country continues to suffer from severe port and transport capacitv constraints. With Eritrea becoming an independent country in May 1993, Ethiopia lost its two traditional ports, Asseb and Massawa, and became landlocked. Although an agreement between the two countries (July 1993) provides Ethiopia unhindered access to Asseb and Massawa, the severe capacity constraints are not likely to permit a significant increase in dry cargo (food and fertilizer) imports. In addition, there are serious transportation constraints aggravated by the inadequacy and poor state of its roads. Ethiopia's road density is among the lowest in Africa, standing at 20 km per 1,000 km2 and 0.4 km per 1,000 population. Some 80 percent of Ethiopians depend on traditional means of transport, such as walking, carrying their goods on the back and head, pack animals and, to a lesser extent, on animal drawn carts. In dispersed, difficult to reach and mountainous locations, where much of the population resides, household food security is a matter of growing concern. 1.4 The Ethiopian political and economic structures have been subject to repeated and profound changes during the past two decades. The 1974 revolution ended an era of monarchy and feudalism. It replaced market mechanisms with state planning and controls over investment, production and trade; stifled private entrepreneurship and diverted resources to the conduct of civil war and virtually crippled the economy. The Mengistu government was defeated in May 1991, and a National Conference, comprising a coalition of 29 parties, ethnic and linguistic groups, installed a Transitional Government (TGE) in June 1991. The TGE is in the process of introducing new economic and administrative structures and a democratic political system. 1.5 Market-oriented Economic System: In November 1991, TGE announced its Economic Policy during the Transitional Period, which signaled a move away from the centrally planned economy towards a more liberal, market-oriented and decentralized economic sysiem in which private, rather than collective ownership, will dominate most sectors of the economy and efficiency will be stimulated by competition and increased international openness. In the meantime, to jump-start the economy, an Emergency Recovery and Reconstruction Project (ERRP), Credit 2351 -ET, was launched in July 1992, in cooperation with other donors, involving a total provision of about US$650 million to be disbursed in two and a half years. ERRP, due to close on September 30, 1995, has been satisfactorily implemented thus far. 1.6 The TGE's first phase of economic reform included a 59 percent devaluation of the Birr (in US dollars terms) in October 1992, and the introduction of a limited biweekly foreign exchange auction system in May 1993, as a move towards a market-determined rate of exchange. Other important reforms aimed at improving incentives for production, competitiveness of markets, and private sector performance. These efforts have been supported by a Structural Adjustment Credit (Cr. 2526-ET) funded by IDA and other donors. The TGE has also agreed with the IDA and IMF on the subsequent phase of reforms presented in the third Policy Framework Paper negotiated in September 1994 for the period 1994-95 to 1996-97.
 -2 - 1.7 Decentralized Administrative System: In order to provide a sound basis for grassroot economic growth with people's participation, TGE divided the country into 14 regions; however, the newly adopted constitution by the Constituent Assembly divides the country into nine states, namely, Tigray, Afar, Amhara, Oromia, Somali, Benishangul, Southern Nation, Gambella and Harare. These state governments shall have legislative, executive and judicial powers in respect to all matters within their geographical areas except certain subjects where the central government alone will have authority. In order to implement the new arrangements, a massive shift of staff from the central government to various regions is under way. It is a major step in the reorganization of the country's administrative system. 1.8 Such simultaneous handling of profound systemic changes in the economic, political, administrative and institutional structures of Ethiopia is an effort of unprecedented magnitude. Inevitably, it will take time to fully establish effective organizational structures and functional relationships to sustain a high level of economic performance in a democratic political environment. B. The Agricultural Sector 1.9 Sectoral Contribution: The agricultural sector is the leading sector in the Ethiopian economy. It accounts for 55 percent of GDP at factor cost, employs 80 percent of the labor force, generates 60 percent of commodity export earnings, in which coffee alone accounts for 60 percent, and provides raw materials for 70 percent of the country's large and medium-sized industrial enterprises that are agro-based. Crop production is estimated to contribute around 60 percent, livestock around 30 percent and forestry, fishery and other sub- sectors around 10 percent of the total sectoral output. An estimated over six million smallholders, farming about 6 to 7 million hectares of land, follow a largely traditional, low-input/low-output rainfed farming technology and account for about 96 percent of all agricultural output, including 98 percent of the coffee. The balance is contributed by state farms and other public agricultural enterprises. Depending on the crop situation, only about 20-30 percent of the cereal production reaches the local market, while the remainder is consumed on the farm. 1.10 Sectoral Performance: The performance of the agriculture sector in the last two decades has been poor. While the economy grew at 2.2 percent during the last 18 years, the annual agricultural growth averaged around 1.1 percent only. The area under crops as well as the overall production has remained stagnant for several years, barring some exceptional years like 1982/83 and 1988/89. The land productivity has also remained low at an average per hectare yield of 1.2 tons for food grains, 0.6 tons for pulses and 0.5 tons for oilseeds compared to relatively much higher yields (more than double in many cases) obtained at research stations and on demonstrations in farmers fields. As a result, barring the exceptional year of 1983, the country has been a net importer of foodgrains since 1981. The level of foodgrain imports required to meet the country's deficit rose from 3 percent of the total grain consumption in early 1980s to about 10 percent in 1990. Further, according to the Central Statistical Authority (CSA) 1988-89 agricultural sample survey, 46.7 percent of 6.09 million households (excluding Eritrea, Tigray, Asseb and Ogaden region) have holdings of less than 0.5 ha; cumulatively, 72.1 percent have holdings of less than one hectare (average size of holding being 0.73 ha). Further, assuming a family size of 5 and normal cereal productivity in Ethiopia, a typical farm household may need about 0.75 ha of land to obtain a food supply of about 0.9 tons per annum to stay above the absolute poverty line. Based on this criteria, over 60 percent of the rural households may be below the poverty line. 1.11 Policy Environment: The absence of a conducive policy environment has probably been the single most important factor which depressed agricultural performance in the last two decades. Since March 1990, however, the policy environment has steadily improved. Producer cooperatives have been dissolved; private commercial farms are being encouraged; public investment in state farms has been drastically reduced; all compulsory foodgrain quotas have been abolished, and free foodgrain trade has been restored. A new
 - 3 - Investment Code has been issued which provides incentives to private investors; countrywide peace has been restored; most of the demobilized soldiers have returned to their farms thereby relieving labor shortages; extension agents have been relieved of their conscription and other political duties, and devaluation of the Birr has largely restored the profitability of agricultural exports. These policy reforms, combined with additional fertilizer support under ERRP in 1992, have already resulted in the highest crop productions in 1992-93 and 1993-94. 1.12 Other Causes of Poor Sectoral Performance include: (a) inadequate research and extension support; (b) virtual freezing of crop production technology at a primitive, level except for the limited introduction of fertilizers; (c) continued poor access to modern farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers; (d) recurrent droughts, little irrigation (about 3 percent of total area) despite significant potential; (e) declining soil fertility due to overgrazing, reduced fallow, and very rapid deforestation (from 16 percent of total land area in the early 1950s, to only 2.7 percent in 1989); and (f) progressively diminishing vegetative cover and declining long-term fertility of soils with 30 percent of the cropped area already facing soil acidity problem. As a result of all these inadequacies in soil management, combined with very low levels of fertilizer application, soil nutrients are virtually being mined. The country has not yet prepared proper soil fertility maps nor put in place a soil testing service for the farmers, and thus is far from developing a clear, integrated soil management-cum-inputs (seeds, pesticides and fertilizer) strategy. Further, the indigenous renewable nutrient resource of animal waste and crop residues stands almost totally diverted to the fuel energy needs of rural households. The possibility of meeting these needs through a more judicious use of animal dung through biogas plants which provide (a) energy for domestic cooking; and (b) slurry to improve the structure, moisture retention capacity and humus in the soils has been successfully tested but not yet tried on a commercial scale. The use of inexpensive, domestically grown (rhizobium cultures) biofertilizers, which fix atmospheric nitrogen in leguminous plants such as pulses and oilseeds, has not been propagated either. Even green manuring and composting are hardly practiced. According to an estimate of the National Conservation Secretariat, the combined impact on agricultural yields from soil erosion and the burning of dung and crop residues resulted in a foregone cereal production of about one million tons in 1990. 1.13 Sources of Growth: The TGE's recent agricultural strategy identifies two main sources of growth in agricultural output: (a) area expansion through (i) extensive mechanized farming and (ii) intensive commercial agriculture; and (b) higher smallholder crop productivity per unit of land. 1.14 (a) Area Expansion: The scope of increasing area under crops in the central highlands, where much of agriculture is currently practiced, is severely limited due to growing population pressure combined wvith one of the largest livestock herds in Africa. Land scarcity has led to increasing the cropped area at the expense of both fallow and grazing, with crops being grown on more marginal, steep and poorly drained lands which are susceptible to erosion. It would, therefore, be necessary for cropped area expansion both for extensive mechanized farming and intensive commercial agriculture, to move to lower elevations, mostly in the west and south of the country where population density is much lower. However, this would entail a considerable amount of lead time and investment, as these areas are generally (i) uninhabited or have a sparse population; (ii) malaria infested; (iii) lacking in minimum infrastructure like roads, clinics, banks, electricity, potable water, schools, and telecommunications; and (iv) deprived of access to cheap labor due to the absence of housing and other facilities. Further, the environmental impact of the sudden opening of large areas of land combined with new human settlements would need a careful study. Area expansion would, therefore, be only a medium to long-term option, and would not significantly address the problem of rising food shortages in the next few years. 1.15 (b) Yield Enhancement: The only available short-term alternative to meet the compelling need for increased foodgrain production is by increasing the land productivity. There are several mutually reinforcing ways of achieving enhanced productivity levels in agriculture. These include widespread use of improved seeds, better cultural practices, site-specific solutions to low productivity through intensive research and extension work, minimization of post harvest losses, greater and more efficient use of chemical and

However, given the current situation in Ethiopia, under which (i) the entire public administration system is being revamped; (ii) the agricultural research and extension system is being reviewed for thorough reform; (iii) work on site-specific crop productivity problems is yet to commence; (iv) the commercial manufacture and sale of improved agricultural implements and thrashers has not commenced; (v) the important institution of rural cooperatives is to be virtually recreated under the new cooperative law; (vi) the Agricultural and Industrial Development Bank (AIDB) and Commercial Bank of Ethiopia (CBE), the two primary institutions for rural credit. are being restructured and recapitalized and (vii) the state farms mainly responsible for limited seed production are being downsized and commercialized; it would be difficult to expect synergistic contributions from several of these options at least for the next few years. Nevertheless, it is possible to begin with some specific initiatives which will progressively draw support from the above mentioned institutional and other improvements. 1.16 Domestic Foodgrain Production and Estimated Needs: Graph 1.1 depicts a 20-year scenario of food production and consumption needs from 1974 to 1994. The country's structural food deficit which started in 1981 is now around one million tons of foodgrain per year; this deficit could rise in the coming years unless the growth rate in domestic food production matched the population growth rate. The urgency of rapidly increasing domestic food production needs to be viewed in the context of (a) port capacity constraints that limit more than ever before the scope of food imports; (b) transportation problems from the ports to inland locations, particularly those which are without access roads; and (c) the fact that 50 percent of the population is already suffering from chronic food insecurity. 1.17 An estimate of Ethiopia's food balance and fertilizer requirement shows that Ethiopia's gross foodgrain requirements would rise from 8.38 million tons in 1994 to 10.73 million tons in 1999 (an increase of 2.35 million tons). This calculation is based on two assumptions: (a) an average annual population growth of 2.7 percent; and (b) an increase in the per capita foodgrain (cereals and pulses) requirement from 134 kg in 1994 to 150 kg in 1999 (still way below the internationally accepted norm of 220 kg). On the other hand, assuming that (a) during 1994 and 1999, domestic food production would rise between 3 to 3.4 percent (which is more than twice the average growth rate in the past 20 years), due to factors like improved economic environment, liberalization of foodgrain markets, marginal increase in area under crops, prevailing peace in the countryside. and improved extension service, but excluding incremental fertilizer use; and (b) the average annual food imports would be maintained at the current level of some 0.8 million tons, the country would still be faced with an increase in the food deficit of 1.04 million tons in 1999. Therefore, the countrv must annually increase its production so as to produce an additional 1.04 million tons of foodgrains in 1999. A plausible solution would be to effectively promote a more widespread and more efficient use of inorganic fertilizers in the country in conjunction with some pilot initiatives to improve the soil fertility status through expanded use of organic sources of nutrients. Given the fertilizer response ratios currently obtained in Ethiopia and the expected improvements during the project, fertilizer use would need to grow at a compound annual growth rate of about 17 percent between 1994 and 1999, in order to keep the average food deficit at the current level of about 0.8 million tons. This growth is considered feasible since the current fertilizer use level is extremely low (paras 2.2 and 2.8) when compared to fertilizer use in several countries in Africa and elsewhere, and because about 80 percent of the Ethiopian farmers are non-users of fertilizers due to several constraints (paras 2.24 to 2.27), many of which can be overcome. On the other hand, importation of 1.8 million tons of foodgrains is not a realistic option, given that the import of grains and distribution is costlier than local production and, more importantly, that the physical constraints to handling such a large volume of grain imports through the port, transportation and distribution systems would be too overwhelming. Fertilizer can play a very significant role in lowering transport costs as one ton of fertilizer substitutes for five tons of grain on the average. 1.18 An important constraint in fertilizer use promotion has been the inadequacy of the agricultural extension service and, particularly the extension agents' lack of training in promoting efficient fertilizer use. The TGE is seriously addressing this constraint. Currently the farmer to extension agent ratio varies widely

A task force, set-up in August 1994, is finalizing extension recommendations for different crops and agro-climatic areas, as well as exploring ways of (a) upgrading the skills of extension agents through well- focused training programs; and (b) ensuring timely and adequate supplies of agricultural inputs-specifically, seeds and fertilizers to farmers. A committee, which was set up in February 1994, has, inter alia, recommended (i) strengthening the extension services in terms of numbers and skills; (ii) strengthening the linkages between research and extension on the one hand and input supplies on the other; (iii) improved mobility of extension workers; and (iv) developing integrated extension services instead of the current fragmented service with allegiance to several departments. These recommendations are under the consideration of TGE. C.  - 6 - II. THE FERTILIZER SECTOR A. Fertilizer Use 2.1 Inorganic fertilizer was first introduced to Ethiopia following three years of simple fertilizer demonstrations (1967-69) on major cereal crops, carried out by the Government with the assistance of FAO's Freedom from Hunger Campaign. It did not take long for the peasants to value the benefit of fertilizer application to their crops. 2.2 Beginning with an average annual consumption of 3,500 tons during 1967-72, the fertilizer usage has continually increased to a record level of 156,000 tons in 1992. Despite this growth, Ethiopia is one of the lowest users of fertilizers in the world. It averages about 7 kilograms of nutrient per hectare of arable land, compared to about 48 kg in Kenya, 60 kg in Zimbabwe, 9 kg each in Tanzania and Sub-Saharan Africa, 65 kg each in the Middle East and North Africa, and 97 kg--the estimated world average. Application rates by most peasant farmers are well below those recommended by the extension service (100 kg DAP and 50 kg Urea per hectare) and may in some cases be as low as 20-30 kg per hectare. The application rates by the state farms, whose consumption peaked to almost 30,000 tons in 1986-87, were much higher at 130 kg per hectare. The 1974 blanket fertilizer use recommendations are now being replaced with more specific crop and soil related recommendations on the basis of several years of data obtained from fertilizer trials carried out in different parts of the country (para 6.1). 2.3 About 85 percent of all fertilizer is used by peasants and much of the remainder is used on the state farms. Nearly 95 percent of all fertilizer is applied on foodgrains. According to a crop survey by CSA in 1982-83 and the more recent Agricultural Inputs Supply Corporation (AISCO) estimates, tef--the major staple-accounts for about 40 percent of all fertilizer used, while wheat, barley, maize, and sorghum altogether account for about 50 percent of all fertilizer consumption--the rest being used on other crops like millet, cotton, coffee and tobacco. Coffee is, in contrast to many other African countries, only a marginal consumer of fertilizers. For 1990-91, CSA estimated its use around 4,000 tons, applied mostly in coffee nurseries. 2.4 Fertilizers are used by an estimated 1.2 million peasants or some 20 percent of the estimated six million fanming families. However, according to the 1989 agricultural Extension Monitoring Survey (EMS), more than two-third of the farmers in the high fertilizer consumption areas are familiar with the blanket fertilizer use recommendations promoted by the Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) extension staff. Several field visits have further revealed that a majority of farmers, including subsistence farmers, in the low-consumption areas are equally aware of the blanket fertilizer use recommendations. 2.5 About 78 percent of fertilizer consumption is concentrated in the highlands, 46 percent in Shewa, and 16 percent each in the Gojam and Arsi regions. An estimated one-third of all farmers in these regions, which account for 60 percent of the cropped area, with 30 percent of the households having less than 0.5 hectare of land, apply fertilizers to their crops. Some 80 percent of the fertilizer sales comprise DAP, urea accounts for 19 percent, and other fertilizers (mostly NPK), one percent. This reflects a serious nitrogen to phosphorous (N:P) nutrient imbalance (1:1.8) in fertilizer use when compared to the extension recommendations (1:1.1). There is an urgent need to increase the use of nitrogenous fertilizers by the farmers. 2.6 While the available data does not permit analysis of fertilizer consumption by farm size, preliminary results of the International Food Policy Research Institute's (IFPRI) survey "Ethiopia: Seasonality Study" in South Shoa indicate that 40 percent of farmers owning 0.5 hectares or less had used fertilizers in 1991. There is anecdotal evidence from some other regions to show that some subsistence farmers also use fertilizers to raise their cereal production to a level which can sustain their families through the year. For this purpose they would sell a goat or a sheep or even an ox to buy some fertilizers. The two most important constraints mentioned by the peasants are (a) scarcity of fertilizer in the nearby markets, and (b) non-availability of credit.
 - 7 - 2.7 The sales season for fertilizers is rather short with about 15-20 percent being sold during the short rainy season (belg) from February to April and the rest being sold during the three months May-July, before and during the main rains (meher) lasting between June and September. There is very little fertilizer sale in August and virtually no sale between September and January. Therefore, unlike the two distinct fertilizer sale seasons, separated by some months in most countries, Ethiopia has virtually only one season, from February to July. This aggravates the logistical problems in fertilizer importation and distribution in Ethiopia. 2.8 Fertilizer Use Potential: Given that fertilizer is used by no more than 20 percent of the farmers and that many farmers apply sub-optimal doses, and given that countrywide trials over several years have established the profitability of fertilizer use in most situations, there is a significant scope for increasing the coverage and the dosage of fertilizer use. These trials, conducted since 1967, have been funded by various donors from time to time. The National Fertilizer Inputs Unit (NFIU) of MOA funded by Italy and managed by FAO, in close collaboration with the Agricultural Development Division (ADD) of MOA, is conducting trials in demonstration plots and farmers fields since 1985 (see para 6.1). The scope of this program is now being expanded to evaluate the role of complementary organic inputs. B. Fertilizer Production 2.9. Ethiopia does not produce chemical fertilizers. However, for the domestic production of inorganic fertilizers, based on the country's natural resource endowment, some initiatives are in the pipeline. The Ministry of Industry has completed a techno-economic feasibility study for putting up a 10,000 ton per annum SSP plant, (20 percent P205) using the annual availability of bones in the country, and the project is likely to be proposed for donor assistance. Some studies have also been made on various aspects of ammonia-urea production based on available domestic resources of natural gas, but a systematic techno-economic feasibility study has not yet been undertaken. The Government proposes to take up further studies out of its own resources or from other grant assistance. Therefore, for all practical purposes, the country must import all its requirement for inorganic fertilizers in the coming several years. C. Fertilizer Policy Environment 2.10 In addition to the macro-policy reforms described in Chapter I, TGE also announced a Fertilizer Policy in November 1993 (see Annex 1). This policy document addresses major issues germane to the liberalization and development of the fertilizer sub-sector. Its policy objectives include: (a) promotion of a streamlined, competitive and efficient fertilizer importation and marketing system; (b) development of an integrated plant nutrient supply system, including biofertilizers and organic manure; (c) development and use of indigenous nutrient materials; (d) fertilizer promotion in less accessible and low use areas; (e) quality control measures; (f) identification and handling of fertilizer related environmental issues; (g) development of sound agronomic packages with fertilizers as an integral part; (h) alleviation of fertilizer demand and supply side constraints; and (i) creation of an institutional structure to systematically implement the national fertilizer policy. Under this policy, the Government would: (a) encourage the private sector to fully participate in the importation, distribution, wholesale and retail trade for fertilizers; (b) promote cooperatives on the basis of voluntary membership under the new law; and (c) restructure and streamline Agriculture Inputs Supply Corporation (AISCO) into an autonomous entity with its own board of directors so that it can operate in a free market in competition with the private sector and cooperatives. Further, the policy document emphasizes monitoring of fertilizer prices and subsidies, helping farmers adjust to the adverse effects of macro-economic changes, and adjusting the pace of subsidy removal programs in accordance with the prevailing conditions.

Fertilizer demand was estimated by AISCO, a monopolist parastatal that had been handling agricultural inputs since 1985, in consultation with the MOA. However, since this demand estimation exercise was generally delayed, AISCO used to go ahead with imports, depending upon the availability of donor funds, and the demand estimates were later used to allocate appropriate quantities of fertilizers to different regions. Upon arrival at Asseb, the fertilizer was handled by a monopolistic parastatal, the Marine Transport Services Corporation (MTSC) and transported some 800 km from Asseb by another parastatal, the Ethiopian Freight Transport Corporation (EFTC). It was stored by AISCO in its six transit warehouses (Addis Ababa, Mojo, Nazareth, Assela, Jimma and Kombolcha) and then transported (average distance 300 km) to about 500 marketing centers (MCs) resorting under the MOA. The MC staff sold the fertilizer against bank credit, or deposit of the cost in a bank, to service cooperatives (also a state institution), who in turn sold the fertilizer, primarily against credit to the farmers. No cash sales across the counter were permitted in MCs, and only about 40 percent of the 4,100 service cooperatives (SCs) were eligible for Bank credit. Groups of farmers could also go to the nearest bank (which could be several miles away), deposit the price of fertilizer, and then return to the MC with a proof of deposit and obtain delivery of fertilizer. No individual farmer could pay cash and buy fertilizer from MC under this arrangement. The entire system was characterized by a complete absence of market orientation. This cumbersome system combined with the Government's tight control on the agricultural sector, including fixed output prices until 1990, has been a major reason for only one out of five farming families using fertilizers and that too in substandard doses. 2.12 New Marketing Strategy (NMS): Following the New Economic Policy of the TGE (November 1991), a new marketing strategy for fertilizer was formulated with technical assistance from FAO. It has seven key elements: (a) to begin with, private sector should supplement and not replace the existing marketing arrangements through MCs and SCs; (b) the playing field should be made level between the cooperatives and the private traders; both should obtain fertilizers from MCs at the same price and with the same distribution margin; (c) the National Bank of Ethiopia (NBE) should permit the Commercial Bank of Ethiopia (CBE), which has an extensive countrywide branch network, to provide fertilizer credit to farmers and fertilizer retailers and wholesalers, thereby breaking the monopoly of the AIDB which had a limited branch network; (d) the extent and pace of privatization in different parts of the country should be in accordance with the likely private sector response, given the local social, political and entrepreneurial situation; (e) eventual elimination of the pan-territorial pricing system and, as a first step, decontrol of retail prices; (f) advocates an active role for the Government in obtaining donor support for adequate and timely import of fertilizers; and (g) regular and intensive monitoring of prices, sales and stocks by AISCO and arrangements to rush supplies to areas where shortages could surface leading to price increases. 2.13 Implementation of NMS: The NMS was implemented except for decontrol of retail prices. AISCO took a number of preparatory steps during February-May 1992, including: (a) developing detailed proposals on distribution of fertilizers in war ravaged areas of Tigray, Wello and Gondar; (b) conducting an orientation program for AISCO's Regional Coordinators; (c) preparing a detailed secondary fertilizer movement plan (i.e., from transit warehouses to MCs); (d) preparing a location-based retail network plan as a basis for the privatization campaign; (e) designing retailer and wholesaler "Application for Registration" form and recognition letter; (f) preparing criteria for the selection of private retailers and wholesalers, with delegation of powers to local officers to appoint them without any registration fee; (g) designing the monitoring forms for fertilizer movement, stocks and sales; (h) preparing a detailed step by step timetable for action; (i) strengthening AISCO's sales and distribution department; and (j) working out realistic distribution margins for wholesalers and retailers in order to make it attractive for the private trade to participate in fertilizer marketing.

The Government sets the maximum retail price for each type of fertilizer on the basis of AISCO proposals duly reviewed by MOA, Ministry of Trade, and the Ministry of Planning and Economic Development. These recommendations are based on cost-plus proposals by AISCO/MOA and now (i.e., since 1992) include distribution margins for retailers. Constraints to Fertilizer Use 2.24 Constraints to fertilizer use are several; the main ones emanate from the country's past macroeconomic environment. In addition, there are supply and demand side constraints. 2.25 Until recently, the macroeconomic policy environment favored complete state control. This brought in some of the most glaring inefficiencies in the system, including high wastage, excessive distribution and
 - 12 - marketing costs, and serious delivery delays. TGE's latest policies (1992-93), however, make a departure from the past by allowing private importation, transportation and domestic marketing of fertilizers, as well as free trading of agricultural output (para 2.15). These reforms would need to be further deepened by abolishing fertilizer (pan-territorial) price controls, (para 2.16) and eliminating the recently introduced 15 percent fertilizer subsidy (paras 2.17 and 2.18); and appointing private forwarding and clearing agents at Asseb to reduce fertilizer handling costs. 2.26 On the supply side, the major constraints include chronic shortages in fertilizer supply at inland locations, particularly outside the currently surplus grain producing areas of Shoa, Arsi and Gojam, and the absence of a well-spread out network of fertilizer retailers. In addition, the delayed deliveries of fertilizers at the retail points are also partly due to the handling inefficiencies of parastatals at the port and those responsible for transportation, and partly due to late announcement of aid by bilateral donors. Such a situation reduces the overall fertilizer consumption and encourages fertilizer use on crops planted later in the season, even if this means fertilizer use on relatively less responsive crops. Fertilizers arriving at Asseb close to the main consumption season suffer from transportation problems because of the poor state of roads, which is made worse with the onset of the rainy season. Also the marketing strategy of AISCO, which did not permit across the counter cash sale, made it very difficult for a small farmer to get his supplies conveniently. 2.27 On the demand side, the main constraints are controlled grain prices and a compulsory quota delivery system, shortage of agricultural credit, poor research, extension and training support to farmers, unwieldy size of fertilizer bags (50 kg), and some technical problems like soil erosion, absence of soil testing facilities, and absence of fertilizer use promotion programs. The most important of the demand side constraints, i.e., controlled grain prices and compulsory quota delivery system, have already been removed. Farmers are now free to sell their produce when they want, to whom they want, and at prices which the market will bear. This has already improved the demand for fertilizers. In 1992, fertilizer use increased by 40 percent, due to three main reasons: (a) improved availability of fertilizers within the country through liberal and timely imports funded by ERRP; (b) higher demand due to improved economic environment; and (c) normal rains. The Government is currently engaged in addressing constraints of inadequate fertilizer credit, extension support to farmers, and absence of soil testing facilities. L. Design Considerations for The Fertilizer Project 2.28 In the design of a fertilizer policy and a fertilizer use development program, some special features deserve to be noted. First, there being no domestic production of inorganic fertilizers, Ethiopia depends completely on imports. There is, therefore, no fertilizer supply push ordinarily originating in fertilizer producing countries from a build-up of inventories in the fertilizer plants during the off-season. Second, in order to obtain significant economies of scale in fertilizer importation and ocean freight, the minimum size of a shipment will need to be around 20,000 tons. This means that, at a minimum, an importer must be able to mobilize about US$5 million for a shipload, and additionally about US$3 million in local currency to meet port charges, bagging, transportation, and distribution costs. Third, from the time of placing orders with a foreign supplier, it takes two to four months for the fertilizer to arrive at interior locations. On the other hand, the fertilizer application season in Ethiopia is short, continuous, time specific and inflexible. Fourth, Ethiopia is now a land-locked country, and priority berthing and emergency handling of fertilizer vessels may not always be possible. Fifth, a considerable amount of uncertainty surrounds the fertilizer business. There is demand uncertainty due to weather aberrations in the rainfed farming systems of Ethiopia. Anticipated output prices and credit availability also influence fertilizer demand at the farm level. There is supply uncertainty, given Ethiopia's total dependence on imports coupled with chronic shortage of foreign exchange and uncertainties in the timing of donor assistance. Supply uncertainties also arise out of unanticipated port congestions and inland transportation problems. There is also price uncertainty due to fluctuations in world fertilizer prices and donors' procurement procedures. Sixth, politically, fertilizer is a sensitive commodity; at
 - 13 - the same time, economically, it is a critical input to mitigate an acute problem of food insecurity. Ethiopia has a significant population amenable to risk posed by famine, starvation and shortfalls in food aid. Also there are logistical constraints at the ports, as well as within the country, including a poor road network, mountainous terrain and inaccessible segments of population. It has been estimated that it is much cheaper, in terms of foreign exchange requirements and the capacity of domestic infrastructure, to import and use fertilizers than to import foodgrains. Lastly, exclusive reliance on chemical fertilizers may not be the sound way to sustain long- term fertility of Ethiopian soils. An approach for complementary use of organic and inorganic nutrient sources for sustaining and enhancing soil fertility could be environmentally more efficient and acceptable (see para 1.12). Therefore, it may be necessary to take some pilot initiatives in this direction. 2.29 From the above, some conclusions follow: (a) it will not be quick or easy to attract the private sector to the fertilizer importation business, as distinguished from domestic marketing, given the needed minimum size of investment and the risks involved; (b) in view of the bulkiness of the fertilizer material and the seasonal nature of demand, it is a high risk and low profit business and would not, therefore, be the most attractive choice for an entrepreneur in an economy which is just opening up; (c) in the initial phase of privatization, when individual entrepreneurs would be cautious in importing or acquiring more fertilizers than they are sure of selling, a scarcity syndrome could not be ruled out and therefore, the planning of transition from a government controlled to a market oriented fertilizer sub-sector needs to be done with extreme caution to avoid convulsive changes in fertilizer flow to the farmer; and, finally, (d) it would be highly desirable to move in the direction of an integrated plant nutrient supply system, instead of relying on chemical fertilizers alone. Lessons Learned 2.30 In view of the reversal of the policies of the previous Government (1974-90) and the adoption of a liberalized market-based approach to economic development by TGE, the lessons of the projects implemented during the earlier regime do not have much relevance in the changed context. However, across countries, a relevant experience relates to Malawi Smallholder Fertilizer Project (Cr. 1352-MAI). The Project Performance Audit Report (PPAR) No. 9689 dated June 21, 1991 concludes as follows: "The main lesson of this operation for the Bank is that, prior to lending, the Bank should draw up explicit plans, seek a firm commitment and reach an agreement with the Government on fostering commercialization of fertilizer procurement and distribution (especially) with proper supervisory and regulatory roles for the MOA or one of its agencies." In the proposed National Fertilizer Sector Project (NFSP), commercialization and privatization of fertilizer importation and distribution and monitoring by the National Fertilizer Industry Agency (NFIA) is the central feature. Further, the PPAR for the Malawi project stated that "the fertilizer project should have been less ambitious in its objective of policy reform and should have been limited to promoting a commercialized distribution system." According to the PPAR, the fertilizer subsidy policy issue was quite properly in the domain of the structural adjustment credit and the agricultural sector credit. In the case of Ethiopia, phased subsidy removal is one of the conditionalities for the NFSP, but IDA would follow a multi- pronged approach and keep it as an important issue under the Policy Framework Paper discussions too. Other relevant fertilizer projects reviewed include Bangladesh First and Second Fertilizer Imports Credits (Cr. 944- BD and 1044-BD) as well as Pakistan Fertilizer Import Credit (Cr. 1066-PK). The PPAR for the Bangladeshi projects conclude that these projects helped increase fertilizer use with a significant impact on foodgrain production. Also the credits helped in easing constraints and laying the foundation for an efficient fertilizer supply and distribution system. The PPAR underlines the need for training the staff of the Fertilizer Planning and Monitoring Secretariat--a missing component in the Bangladesh Imports Credits. The lessons from these projects have been incorporated in the design of the NFSP. 2.31 An important lesson from the Ugandan and Kenyan experience is that a macroeconomic program by itself would not generate immediate and adequate private sector response in the fertilizer sector. It takes much longer to create a conducive environment. What is more important, the private sector needs time, to develop
 - 14 - confidence in the new policies as well as in the continuity and stability of the new macroeconomic environment. Given a range of choices among the new business opportunities, fertilizer is certainly not the most attractive choice, as the fertilizer business is characterized by the acute seasonality of demand, total dependence on imports, the need for high capital requirement for even one shipload, and the need for an elaborate domestic marketing network. The experience in Ghana shows that privatization of fertilizer marketing increased the concentration of the distribution network in urban areas. While many of the official distribution channels had shut down, private traders had not rushed in to replace them. This had particularly hit the small farmers in remote areas. Financial Aspects 6.1 The Proritability of Fertilizer Use: Technical and financial aspects related to fertilizer use have been studied for more than a quarter of a century in Ethiopia. It began with the FAO--Freedom from Hunger Campaign's fertilizer trials program in the highlands--the bread basket of the country. In 1985, the program of fertilizer trials expanded under the Italian funded, FAO managed, National Fertilizer and Inputs Unit (NFIU). The NFIU in collaboration with the Agricultural Development Division (ADD) of the MOA, has been focusing on further refinement of the country-wide blanket fertilizer application recommendations by (food grain) crop, region and soil type; it has expanded its fertilizer trial activities to the low fertilizer-use areas with potential. The most recent data on fertilizer profitability in different crop and soil situations were presented by NFIU during a workshop held in Addis Ababa on July 2, 1993: profitability is expressed in the Value Cost Ratio (VCR)2. The NFRP experience reveals average VCRs of about 3.0 for teff and wheat, 4.0 for maize, 3.0 for barley and 2.2 for sorghum. These values clearly confirm the profitability of applying fertilizer on rainfed crops, as these are in excess of 2.0--the generally accepted minimum level. 6.2 NFIU's most recent VCRs have been subjected to further analysis through variation in (a) yield; (b) arm size; and (c) hired labor requirements. It emerges from the supplemental analysis that a 10 percent reduction of incremental yields negatively impacts the profitability of fertilizer only for sorghum and wheat in the Gondar and Wollo areas, as the VCRs would drop to 2.0, i.e., the minimum level at which a farmer would consider applying the recommended dosage of fertilizer at the current prices for produce and inputs. More interestingly the supplemental analysis reveals that fertilizer use under non-mechanized (and thus labor intensive) farming conditions is a worthwhile proposal only for farms of a size of 2.5 ha or less, irrespective of the regions; fertilizer is rightly perceived as expensive by the farmers who crop more than 2.5 ha in a labor intensive manner. Fertilizer is a relevant tool for increasing smallholder farm incomes, particularly in Ethiopia where 98 percent of all holdings are below 2.5 ha and where mechanized peasant farming is virtually non-existent. 6.3 Farm Income Analysis: The farm income analysis focused on the typical (average) farm types in five provinces: Gojam, Shewa, Arsi, Gondar, and Wollo. Of these Gojam, Shewa and Arsi are known to be relatively high fertilizer consumption areas. Gondar and Wollo are areas where fertilizer consumption is below national average. Surveys have revealed, and field trips have confirmed, that farmers in these areas are familiar with the benefits of fertilizer. Average holding and household size is, in each of the aforementioned five selected areas, very close to the national average. Regional differences in cropping patterns, yields, and (NFIU) fertilizer recommendations, as well as prices of produce and inputs, are accounted for in the farm income analysis. 6.4 The results of the farm income analysis are summarized in a tabular form, for the With and the Without fertilizer case Annex 10. The analysis reveals that the average net farm incomes in Gojam, Shewa and Arsi are about Birr 1,000 per year without fertilizer, and about Birr 1,600 with fertilizer, applied according to NFIU recommendations. Average net farm incomes in Gondar and Wollo are only Birr 800 per year without fertilizer and about Birr 1,200 with fertilizer; the 20 to 25 percent lower incomes in these areas are the result of less favorable agro-ecological conditions as compared to Gojam, Shewa and Arsi.  -45- Annex 1 Page 1 of 12 TRANSMONAL GOVERNMENT OF ETHIOPIA NATIONAL FERTILIZER POLICY (November 1993) I. Introduction 1. Agriculture is the main stay of the Ethiopian economy. Mixed farming and pure livestock based production systems are dominant in the highlands and lowlands of Ethiopia, respectively. The mixed production system has been practiced for centuries. Because of the inter-dependence of the animal husbandry and crop production practices, the support extended by each has been a key factor for their coexistence. Plant nutrient recycling has been and still is an integral part of the mixed production system. Despite the intense agricultural practices in the mixed farming areas, the system has remained productive and, hence, needs to be supported and strengthened through the infusion of relevant new technologies. 2. Current grain production does not meet the food requirement of the population. Projections show that the population will continue to grow at a faster pace and, hence, contribute immensely to the severity of food deficit. Agricultural productivity in general and yield per unit area in particular have to be improved significantly if food deficit problems are to be minimized and finally eliminated. In this regard, diffusion and adoption of new and improved technology including the use of fertilizers will play a critical role. Fertilizer consumption during the last 20 years has been increasing and it has contributed towards increasing crop production. Increased use of fertilizer along with improved practices of the indigenous know how will continue to contribute to agricultural production provided that there is an extended and intensive distribution of fertilizer outside the established fertilizer consuming areas. 3. Inappropriate economic policies, weak infrastructure, lack of market outlets, and centrally controlled pricing systems were among the major drawbacks which affected agricultural production, productivity and income of the farming communities. This had serious implication on fertilizer use since the purchasing power of farmers will be severely limited even if fertilizers were available. It is believed that the market-oriented policies pursued by the Government, coupled with intensive extension services, and provision for credit facilities would create incentives to increase farmers productivity and hence, would help to improve the weakened purchasing power of smallholders. 4. Lack of policy and guidelines on importation, pricing, distribution and marketing of fertilizer use together with limited research information, lack of resources and services, poor infrastructure, mismanagement of natural resources, centralized pricing policies of the past, limited diffusion of information and to a certain extent unfavorable climatic conditions have been responsible for the poor performance of the agricultural sector. 5. The profitability of fertilizers would be optimized when used in conjunction with improved seed, efficient water and land management, and sound cultural practices. Availability of technological packages will thus help intensify fertilizer use. In the absence of full-fledged technological packages, however, use of genetic materials that are productive under existing natural fertility conditions would have to be encouraged and promoted. In this connection TGE has given much emphasis to the development of the agricultural sector and as a result policies and guidelines on seed industry, agricultural research, plant genetic resources, forestry, science and technology, chemical industry, minimizing and energy have been and are being developed. In addition to the trade subsector, the Govermnent has taken measures to liberalize wholesale and retail trade, thus offering opportunities for the privatization of fertilizer marketing at all levels. Such measures will have a positive impact on fertilizer use and development. To provide guidelines and to further facilitate the promotion and development of the subsector, a national fertilizer policy has become imperative.

Until 1992, AISCO was the sole agency responsible for importing and distributing fertilizers in Ethiopia. The timing of fertilizer arrivals at Asseb port was essentially donor driven; often substantial quantities of fertilizers arrived near or after the close of the fertilizer season. This heavy inventory was carried forward for several months and the carrying cost, then estimated to be around 13 percent of the distribution cost, was simply built into the administered price. However, with the liberalization of imports in 1993, profitability considerations are inducing importers to carefully determine the timing of imports in order to minimise their inventory carrying costs. Given that fertilizer sales begin in February-March and (almost) completely end in August, every importer would prefer to get his supplies between February and April, after which heavy countrywide rains make transportation to most consumption areas very difficult. 2. Scheduling the arrival of fertilizer ships near the commencement of the season should ordinarily not be a cause for worry if adequate infrastructure by way of port and inland transport capacity was available to handle the entire quantity between February and April. Unfortunately, however, there are serious capacity constraints at Asseb port; it has only one deep water berth for unloading imported fertilizer which, for reasons of economy, must come in shiploads of 20,000 tons or more. With the current average daily discharge rate of 1,050 tons, a 20,000 ton ship takes about 20 days to unload fully. Accordingly, during February and April, i.e. in 89 days a maximum of 4.5 ships can be unloaded, assuming back to back arrival (which itself is somewhat unrealistic). Against this, in the Project Year 3, about 260,000 tons of fertilizer material is likely to arrive; this would be equivalent of 13 shiploads, needing 260 days, i.e., 8.7 months to unload. This implies that fertilizer unloading must start in mid-september. Even allowing for an occasional smaller ship of 10,000 tons, which can be handled at a smaller berth, and even allowing for significant improvement (say 30 percent) in the fertilizer unloading rate by introducing dockside bagging etc., discharge of the first vessel must begin in late october; thereafter the fertilizer ships should arrive on a continuous basis. [It may be noted here that the situation of Massawa port would not permit more that a small, say, a 10,000 ton vessel being unloaded there. The only other port viz. Djibouti could probably be available from PY 3, provided the road between Djibouti and Dire Dawa and/or the railway system between the samne stations is extensively repaired and the security situation improves.] 3. Such advance arrival would mean significantly higher inventory carrying costs, which no importer would be willing to incur in a competitive marketing system, lest he should be priced out. And yet, because of infrastructure constraints, there is no escape from advance stocking to meet the projected demand for fertilizers. It is, therefore, considered advisable that to encourage such advance stocking, the Government should evolve suitable mechanisms so that the early importers-whether AISCO or private sector do not suffer on account of the extra inventory cost (interest and storage charges) from the time of ship arrival until the end of January. 4.  -93- Annex 12 ETHIOPIA NATIONAL FERTILIZER SECTOR PROJECT Poverty and Gender Issues A. Poverty Issues 1. Present indications are that about 50 percent of the rural households in Ethiopia may be in absolute poverty with food consumption levels giving less than 80 percent of the requirements. Higher agricultural output, which the National Fertilizer Sector Project will make possible, could yield a positive impact on poverty alleviation and nutritional welfare in three ways: (a) by increasing food supplies in households with less than 0.5 ha of land (about 46 percent of all rural households) to enable increases in consumption to meet a minimum critical level of consumption of around 70 to 75 percent of requirements from the present levels of around 40 to 50 percent; (b) increasing food supplies in households prone to transitory poverty (those having between 0.5 and 1.0 ha of land constituting about 34 percent of all farm households) to enable adequate levels of nutrition; and (c) by increasing agricultural output in relatively better-off farms which may provide indirect benefits to the poor through increased opportunities for labor incomes in farms and marketing activities. 2. These prospects for significant poverty alleviation through increased crop productivity call for concerted actions to assist the small-holder peasant sector by way of assuring timely availability of institutional credit, providing effective extension services and making available fertilizers to meet the needs of the poor and marginal farmers. In particular, providing fertilizer in smaller size bags (eg. 25 kg bags) may help adoption. Small farmers in the low-potential areas face relatively high levels of production risks and have low economic capacity to undertake innovations. The NFSP's "Minikit" program could be innovatively used to launch current fertilizer non-users in the low-potential areas, especially those in the war-affected areas, into fertilizer use. Hence, this program should have special focus in these areas. This demonstration program also can bring about some additional income to the farmers which they can utilize for fertilizer purchases in the next season. B. Gender Issues 3. The welfare of women in agricultural households depends to a large extent on the level of overall resources available in the family and on the degree to which women have command over these resources. Increased agricultural productivity increases resource availability and enables greater nutritional welfare to the family. Where intra-household food distribution behavior has disfavored women (and children), increased overall food availability will tend to relax the constraints that induce such behavior. From the perspective of fertilizer use, two major avenues are available to increase women's command over resources: One is by enabling an increased share of women's input in the fertilizer-related incremental output; the other is by enabling women to increase their incomes from homestead agriculture through fertilizer use. Extension services have to play a crucial role in both these areas, Women should be treated as co-equal partners in agriculture when providing extension and other support services. In addition, the proposed restructuring of cooperatives should clearly recognize the role women can play in income generating activities in general, and in credit markets, in particular, both as users of credit and as savers of surplus incomes. 4. The NFSP proposal to promote the production of bio-gas using dung will help women by (a) providing a more efficient and smoke-free cooking environment which will release a considerable amount of women's time for other household or income generating activities; and (b) by allowing the use of slurry to increase productivity of their home gardens. Considering the many benefits of a bio- gas program - better environmental management, women's welfare and income generation - it deserves to be promoted even if it involves a social subsidy.

doc.abstracts: The objective of the National Fertilizer Development Project is to help achieve accelerated and sustainable growth in agricultural production and productivity with a view to improving food security and reducing poverty. The project is expected to achieve this objective by: a) supporting policy reform to create an enabling environment for the growth of a competitive fertilizer sector; b) supporting institutional strengthening and human resource development; c) promoting increased, efficient and environmentally safe use of fertilizers by the largest possible number of farmers; d) addressing fertilizer supply-side constraints; and e) promoting initiatives to maintain and improve the long-term fertility of the Ethiopian soils and ensuring environmental conservation. By the end of the project period, it is envisaged that Ethiopia's fertilizer sector would have moved from a state controlled to a largely liberalized system with active participation of private sector importers, distributors, wholesalers and retailers in a progressively competitive price and trade environment. This, in turn, is expected to contribute significantly to enhanced food security at the national and household levels, improved management of the Ethiopian soils and the strengthening of fertilizer related institutions.
